title: 103_s293
content: The Native American Veterans' Memorial Establishment Act may be cited as the Short Title. The Act includes findings related to Native American veterans. The Congress finds that Native Americans have a long tradition of service in the armed forces of the United States, historically serving in numbers exceeding their representation in the population. Native Americans have also made sacrifices in the cause of peace, with the National Museum of the American Indian established as a living memorial to Native Americans. The National Museum of the American Indian was established as a living memorial to Native Americans. It is an extraordinary site and an ideal location to establish a National Native American Veterans' Memorial. This memorial would further the purposes of the museum by giving all Americans the opportunity to learn of the proud and courageous tradition of service of Native Americans in the armed forces of the United States. Authorization for establishment of memorial. The Board of Trustees of the National Museum of the American Indian is authorized to design, construct, and maintain a National Native American Veterans' Memorial. The Board shall select a suitable site for the Memorial within the facility provided for by the National Museum of the American Indian Act. They are also authorized to hold a competition to select the design of the Memorial. Trustees authorized to hold a competition to select the design of the Memorial. Board may accept, retain, and expend donations for the purpose of designing, constructing, or maintaining the Memorial. The United States Government shall not pay any expenses of the establishment of the Memorial other than providing the site referred to in subsection (b). The "Native American Veterans' Memorial Establishment Act of 1993" defines terms like "Native American," "Indian," "Native Hawaiian," and "Alaska Native." It also establishes the short title of the Act and findings related to the establishment of the Memorial. The Congress recognizes the significant contributions and sacrifices of Native American veterans in the Armed Forces, including their high representation and valor in service. The National Museum of the American Indian serves as a memorial to advance knowledge of Native American cultures and their contributions to society. The National Museum of the American Indian highlights the contributions of Native American veterans in the Armed Forces. Establishing a National Native American Veterans' Memorial at the museum would allow all Americans to learn about the proud tradition of service by Native Americans. The Act defines key terms such as "Native American," "Native Hawaiian," and "Alaska Native." It also establishes the Native American Veterans' Memorial and references the National Museum of the American Indian. The Museum is authorized to design, construct, and maintain a National Native American Veterans' Memorial within its facility in consultation with Native American groups. A competition will be held to select the design, and donations are accepted for the Memorial's expenses. The United States Government will not pay for the expenses of establishing the National Native American Veterans' Memorial, except for providing the site.
